questions.question_text: A web application is unable to authenticate customers so they can access their bills. The server administrator has tested the LDAP query but is not receiving results. Which of the following is the NEXT step the server administrator should take to correct the problem?

choices.A: Check port 636 to see if it is being blocked.
choices.D: Verify the browser is using port 443.

discussion.content: @fathydd...if you change from port 636 to port 389, you just made the connection unsecure. Customers reviewing billing information should do so on a secure connection. Doesn't specifically say what kind of billing information in the question, but there's no telling what kind of PPI is stored on the user's account then they log in to view their bill.
This Question is stupidly easy if you're not studying and listening to people like fathydd you will FAIL.

The correct answer is A. Check port 636 to see if it is being blocked.
It is LDAP protocol over TLS/SSL.
It seems that LDAP query failed because port 636 is blocked.

comments.content: Yes this is correct. LDAP might be used within your domain but over the web you would be using SLDAP and that uses port 636

discussion.content: Read the question. The question is about LDAP but also about the customer authenticating to pay bills, ergo LDAPS port 636.
This is a network methodology question. So the answer is clearly A since LDAP is involved

The exam q probably read LDAPS not LDAP. But as written, B is the correct answer. Keep in mind, dump questions on the internet aren't exactly accurate. However most people seem to understand the port numbers involved and if you understand that, the exam q's, from what I understand, aren't set up to trick you.

comments.content:
LDAP used port 389 and is unsecure. LDAPS uses port 636 and is secure. The administrator should have been checking the secure protocol, but checked the insecure on by mistake. Given the information provided, we are expected to be able to determine the BEST answer - by MIND READING. :) But, in all fairness, this type of scenario happens all the time. (We get no result on port 80, so we automatically check port 443.)

Answer B would downgrade LDAPS (secure) to LDAP (unsecure), but that would make the internet traffic vulnerable to eavesdropping.

Answer C should be avoided at all cost, unless absolutely necessary (and usually during a scheduled maintenance window).

Answer D will verify the browser is using HTTPS, but won’t help remedy the situation.

Answer A is the BEST answer.

discussion.content: This wording is ridiculous, there is no mention of LDAPS, it mentions only LDAP which operates at port 389 so why would checking port 636 change anything? Could someone please explain this to me?
I think the answer is D. If we are talking about billing information we should use HTTPS (port 443).

comments.content: The problem is with LDAP, not HTTPS.
It is LDAP and not LDAPS

discussion.content: B is the correct answer

questions.question_text: Which of the following is networking stand-alone hardware that will permit any WiFi-compliant device to connect to a wired network?

discussion.content: This is why they call Access Points as bridges. Keyword "WiFi -> to wired network"

802.11ac and 802.11n are the most correct answers. Both standards are capable of operating at 5GHz. Even though 802.11n can also operate at 2.4GHz, because it can also use 5GHz, it qualifies.
802.11b, g, and Bluetooth use 2.4GHz to operate.
Z-Wave uses 908.42MHz to operate.
and only 802.11n and 802.11ac can run at 5GHz frequency beside 802.11a

comments.content: You can disable 2.4 Ghz thus allowing only 5GHz

discussion.content: 802.11n doesn't exclusively run 5 GHz, it can run either 2.4 GHz or 5 GHz or both.

questions.question_text: A network technician is installing a new wireless network in a small office. Due to environmental concerns, the customer wants the network to run exclusively on the 5GHz frequency. Which of the following wireless technologies should the technician install to BEST meet this requirement? (Choose two.)
Which of the following concepts would BEST describe when a company chooses to use a third-party vendor to host and administer a critical application?

discussion.content: The answer is SAAS. Under IAAS and PAAS You manage the application. Under SAAS the application is administered

SAAS = You control nothing... Vendor controls everything (Salesforce.com, Google apps, etc...)
PAAS = You control only the app... Vendor controls servers, storage, network, and OS (Azure, etc...)
IAAS = You control app & OS... Vendor controls servers, storage, and network (AWS, Rackspace, etc...)
On PREM = You control everything... Vendor controls nothing

This question says the "vendor hosts and administers... the app". They are doing everything. You are doing nothing. They are hosting and administering the app, even if it's yours. That matches SAAS.

Keep in mind, exam dumps are mostly created by test takers' "memory". So the questions are most likely not exact, nor are the answers always correct. Use them for what they are, do not memorize answers, verify and research what you don't know and you'll do great on the exam!

comments.content: I agree, SaaS. Thanks for the great explanation.

By your own definitions you answered the question wrong. This is a PaaS as the app is only hosted and administered by the third party, it isn't owned by the third party vendor. The given answer is correct.
Source: My husband who is a Solutions Architect with AWS.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The answer is PaaS
'a company chooses to use a third-party vendor to host the application'
Given answer is correct— Read carefully, it is the company, not the third party, that is looking to host

Selected Answer: C
IaaS - When you rent a cloud service on which you install the operating system of your choice, administer the operating system and install the applications of your choice. You just rent the Infrastructure, the rest is up to you. Ex: Virtual Machines in Azure.
SaaS - When you rent a cloud service in which you will use their Software and only do minor additional configuration. You have rented their Software to use. Ex: Microsoft 365 which is made up of Office Online (Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Outlook), OneDrive, Skype, Teams, Exchange and SharePoint Online.
PaaS - When you rent a cloud service on which you will use their Platform and their Platform is already pre-prepared for you to host your own application and administer it. Therefore, it is widely used by developers to host their applications on the internet. After there they find all the tools and resources that their Application needs. Like Databases, Code Editors, etc. Eg: Firebase.
So answer C (PaaS) is correct.

PaaS SaaS
Applications- You manage Applications-Others Manage
Data- You Manage Data-Others Manage
Runtime-Others manage Runtime-Others Manage
Middleware-others manage Middleware-Others manage
OS-Others manage OS-Others Manage
Virtualization-Others manage Others Manage
Servers-Others manage Servers-Others Manage
Storage-Others manage Storage-Others Manage
Networking-Others manage Networking-Others Manage
Host my Application.... I don't need to use "their" software. I need to use their Platform to host my APP.

The answer is SAAS. It stats in the question that the company will "use a third-party vendor to host and administer" the application. If the company was going to administer the application then I would go with PAAS.

Given answer (C. PaaS) is correct.

"A PaaS provider gives programmers all the tools they need to deploy, administer, and maintain a Web application."
-Mike Meyers, Network+ Certification Exam N10-006, pg. 572

And as others have pointed out, the key word is "host" meaning a third party is providing a platform.

Which of the following concepts would BEST describe when a company chooses to use a third-party vendor to host and administer a critical application?
Ask yourself, "who is hosting and administering this app?"
answer: the company
ask yourself, how is the company going to do so?
answer: through a 3rd party
PaaS is the correct anwer.
Read it like this: Which of the following concepts would BEST describe when a company chooses to use a third-party vendor *so it (the company) can* host and administer a critical application? PaaS.
Very tricky question. You have RE-READ it to understand why it's PasS, as it sounds like SaaS on first read.
If the answer is PAAS wouldnt that mean you rather than the vendor manages the application?
Could be either SaaS or PaaS. I think PaaS is more common as SaaS apps are O365, Salesforce etc. Based on the initial details it seems is something internally developed.
Keyword "host" meaning a third party is providing a platform.
A should be the correct answer according this https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/overview/what-is-saas/
Paas is correct - third-party vendor to host and administer a critical application

Platform as a service (PaaS) or application platform as a service (aPaaS) or platform-based service is a category of cloud computing services that provides a platform allowing customers to develop, run, and manage applications without the complexity of building and maintaining the infrastructure typically associated with developing and launching an app

I don't like this. My instinct would have been to put SaaS but as i research I am finding ways to convince myself it is PaaS as they provide application platforms. How reliable are these answers I am half-way thru and feel like I see 10 or more mistakes.

"host and ADMINISTER a critical application" = SAAS
SaaS uses the web to deliver applications that are managed by a third-party vendor
The 3rd party is hosting your app. That means you're the one developing it, hence PaaS

comments.content: The question never never said whose application it is. It just says a critical application. Moreover it says the 3rd party is not only hosting but also administering that application which makes it SaaS all day everyday. A is the correct answer!

discussion.content: IaaS is correct answer
Isn't PaaS used by developers? shouldn't the answer be A?

comments.content: If you understand MAC addresses and switches, you should understand sticky and how it works. Study more.
Comes under Port Security as per Sybex book CompTIA Network+ Review Guide Fifth edition (Jon Buhagiar).

bruh, you could have just answered his question lol.

Its most likely in 1.8 or 4.2 since each section touches on MAC reservations and MAC filtering, respectively, will probably touch on the concept of Sticky MAC to contrast it with DHCP reservation.

discussion.content: where is Sticky Mac on the exam objectives?
This is the first I have heard of "sticky MAC". I never seen this term on the Network + objectives.

Answer is A. But once again CompTIA words their questions like absolute morons.
Sticky mac doesn't "dynamically assign" a layer 2 address. It learns the layer 2 address and retains it so that it can restrict access to that device.

jason dion has a question about stick macs for those of you thinking its not in the objectives, you are misinformed.
OBJ-4.2: Persistent MAC learning, also known as Sticky MAC, is a port security feature that enables an interface to retain dynamically learned MAC addresses when the switch is restarted or if the interface goes down and is brought back online. This is a security feature that can be used to prevent someone from unplugging their office computer and connecting their own laptop to the network jack without permission since the switch port connected to that network jack would only allow the computer with the original MAC address to gain connectivity using Sticky MAC.
I'm curious as to what Net+ objective this would fall under?

comments.content: You should know what sticky is if you understand switches and MAC addresses, it's basic switch security. You have sticky and you have static MAC
this is not taught for Net+

discussion.content:
Sticky MAC is a port security feature that dynamically learns MAC addresses on an interface and retains the MAC information in case the Mobility Access Switch reboots.

Sticky MAC is an alternative to the tedious and manual configuration of static MAC addresses on a port or to allow the port to continuously learn new MAC addresses after interface-down events. Allowing the port to continuously learn MAC addresses is a security risk. Sticky MAC prevents traffic losses for trusted workstations and servers because the interface does not have to relearn the addresses from ingress traffic after a restart.

reference: https://community.arubanetworks.com/browse/articles/blogviewer?blogkey=b00359e1-4cf0-428c-8b39-00992bb60042
You can't use Sticky Mac to both assign and limit traffic?

questions.question_text: Which of the following security mechanisms dynamically assigns a Layer 2 address and restricts traffic only to that Layer 2 address?
